bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, May 23, 1956

div1.p: Lambert wants help to get a bill introduced to honor Ames. Lambert is willing to renounce his claim for recognition if he fails to prove to the Senate committee the importance of Ames.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, May 23, 1956
div1.opener:
12 A
GUST E. LAMBERT
17092 LINCOLN STREET
HAZEL CREST, ILLINOIS
May 23 - 56
Dr Philip Hench
Dear Doctor
div1.p:
In your last letter to me you asked if I needed
any help, my answer was that I needed help to
get a bill introduced to honor Dr Ames, as
Congressmen are adverse to assist any one except
their own constituents, I don't know what to do.
If the Hon. Overton Brooks of La. should be asked by
the world famous Doctor Hench to introduce a
bill, I hardly think he would refuse. If Mr Brooks
who is the leading member of the armed forces
committee will introduce the bill there would
be a chance for an immediate hearing and if
I were allowed to testify I think I would be willing
to renounce my claim for recognition if I should
fail to prove to the committee that without Dr Ames
there would have been no experiment. My bill have
passed the House and is now in the Senate but
who am I? That I should be recognized before Dr
Ames. You know Doctor General Truby wrote in
his book, the success of experiment depended on
Dr Ames. Doctor will you help in this? Please let
me know.
div1.closer:
Very Respectfully Gust E Lambert 17092-Lincoln Str
Hazel Crest Ill
